posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm the Anon who posted in previous threads about losing his grandfather. Grandpa had been living with dementia and had been injured in a fall last week.
On Saturday my father told me that they were going to take Grandpa off a respirator yesterday to see if he could breathe on his own, but if he couldn't they were going to transition to end-of-life care. Mercifully he died peacefully Sunday morning before my family had to make that decision, but honestly I was not expecting his passing right away. My instincts Saturday told me that there was a good chance things wouldn't end well and that I should prepare for my Grandpa's death, but I thought it would be more gradual than it was when my Dad called me yesterday morning.
To be completely honest I have zero experience with any close family dying, and I feel very fortunate to have made it to 30 with all of my loved ones in my life. Given that, I am trying to figure out whether or not I'm grieving correctly. I fly back home tomorrow but so far I've been going about my business like normal and have not been outwardly emotional. Privately I have been sentimental but not a blubbering mess like I always thought I would be. Out of all my grandparents I was closest with and connected most with my grandpa. I know he missed me when I moved away from home and I missed how he was before he started to fade mentally but I was still glad I could talk with him and hug him and have his company when I visited him last month.
Does anyone know if I can refer to anything to help me better understand the thoughts I'm going through? Most guides to grieving a grandparent seem to focus more on helping children cope than adults.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I am nearly 37 years old and for the past 20 years I've been grinding for nothing. I've been afraid to live and I've thrown away every opportunity that might've led to happiness. I have nobody left that I can really call a true friend because I was never a true friend to anyone. I resent my family for being the reason I'm not dead or in prison. For 20 years I've buried my fear under drugs, alcohol, porn and videogames.

Late last year I tried to make a positive change. I stopped watching porn. I stopped drinking and taking drugs. I still play videogames, but that's dying off too.

Ironically, finally making these changes has opened my eyes to the true extent of my failure and it's crushing me. I feel like someone I love has died.

I don't know what to do but wallow in my self pity in the place that's held me hostage for the past 17 years and spill everything to a bunch of people who are probably young enough to be my children. Pathetic, isn't it?

To anyone who gets this far, my advice is to keep going. Don't let your fear stop you. Talk to them. Keep searching. Keep trying. I'm going to get through it and so are you.

posts.com: What I've noticed working in healthcare is that the more unhealthy a person is, the more they believe in apocalypse shit. It's a manifestation of death anxiety. A 50 year old, healthy guy might wave it off as something that'll happen eventually within his lifetime. But a 70 year old with edema and blood pooling in his legs because his ticker is giving out? That guy will be convinced the end is nigh 100% of the time.

I've spent probably most of the past 6 or 7 years retreating inward and finding any excuse to avoid personal responsibility. For whatever reason I had no interest in socializing for the latter half of my adolescence and now as a young adult I hate myself for it because I am extremely lonely and don't know how to talk to people anymore because of the isolation. I crave relationships with people both friendly and romantic but I am terrified of being rejected, and my mind has been so poisoned from years of internet usage that I think I've alienated myself so much from the average person that I'll never be able to click with them, because it seems like normal people can automatically tell when I'm not "one of them".

I don't know what in my brain made me want to isolate myself as a kid and teenager because now I desperately want to escape it and I feel like it's too late. I feel like people think if you haven't worked out your "weirdness" by the time you're an adult then you're to be avoided because like I said you're not one of them and they know.

I wouldn't say that I hate myself but there's not a lot I like about me and I have no motivation to try and improve.

I have no motivation to do anything really. I've spent the past year of my life just going through the motions. Just trying to make it to the end of the day, and the next day.

I spend my days trying to function like a normal person and do a pretty shitty job at it. I spend my nights pacing and trying to keep myself distracted, with occasional random bursts of energy where I get a little work done but not very much. On weekends I just try to keep my mind occupied the whole day and try to forget about the outside world.

I feel like I make people uneasy simply by being in their presence. Not uneasy in the "ooh this guy might be a threat" way, but the "this guy kind of creeps me out" way. Either that or they just sense that I'm a weirdo and automatically want nothing to do with me simply for that.

I mean,

You need to try and discern: is this fundamentally an honest man trying to make his way amidst a very unstable and unfavorable world, or is it someone less than honest, with an immutable personality disorder, who has put on a nice fireworks show for you? I suspect the way to figure this out is to look very closely at how he has acted towards his friends, relatives, past girlfriends if he had any. Did he abandon them, or alienate them all, for example? That would indicate that you might end up in the same pile. Past behavior predicts future behavior, and this applies to how your life tofether will go. Or is he, conversely, still in a tight lifelong friend group and a significant man in the life of his siblings or nephews, for instance.

As someone who is not honest or good, I can tell you that the bad guys will always be initially more interesting than the good guys. More colorful, more exciting, more self-aware. However, behind this colorful façade you will find internal deficiencies and insecurities, and a quicksand that is ALWAYS dysfunctional long-term.
The good guys are very simple to figure out: they are honest and transparent, and so are their lives. And the beauty in this formula is that honesty isn't impossible to identify. By its nature, it should be right there, bland and obvious, written into his routine and accomplishments and relationships.
Needless to say, if you choose the colorful and dishonest and exciting, you'll not be able to build something lasting, and before you know it you're 32 and full of regrets.
So the ultimate question is simply: "is this someone honest?". And yeah, the honest ones will seem a tad autistic. Take it, or alternatively be taken along for long, harrowing, broken rollercoaster rides into bitter solitude with LOTS of cats.

Plus my mother saw me as the chain keeping her bound to my father, a man that couldn't emancipate himself from his own father.
I was sometimes weaponized by my parents against each other.
The result is that it subconsciously convinced me, in the deeper layers of my mind, that I was a mistake, or worse, the "thing that should not be". This led me to self annihilation habits where my body should suffer and be ultimately shred to pieces so that nobody could acknowledge I existed. Death was not enough in a sense.

Hello /adv/ I am a 30 year old American Buddhist Monk living in the US currently at a Monastery.

I've been a monk since 2018 and studying Buddhism and meditation since 2015.

Here to answer any questions and give advice from the position of a Buddhist Monk.

Please don't hesitate to ask anything and I'm quite happy to be here and answer.

I'm not a guru, not enlightened, don't think I'm better than anyone here.

Just here to help out and share what little bit of peace and wisdom that I've been able to experience from my life as a Monk and Buddhist meditator.

Peace and look forward to your questions.

posts.name: Monk
posts.com:
>>28237986
Don't know. Haven't died yet

But on a more serious note from the Buddhist perspective we look at birth and death is happening moment by moment.

So something along the lines of there is a self-like experience coming up right now and that self-like experience is also passing away right now.

And we have this idea that a particular self-like experience is not the same self-experience as will be happening a few moments from now or a week from now or when the conditions change.

So that's a part of Buddhist psychology is that we see this idea of a self that is born and dies as something very fluid and changing moment by moment..

>>28238002
Maybe it's like that but whether it's like that or not I think what's more valuable and important is to take a close and contemplative look at what the actual situation is according to what we can understand from our own experience.

Now it may be something you're interested in or something you're not interested in so you have to determine that for yourself.

But I always go by the rule of don't disrespect your own curiosity or your own interest Don't minimize your own capacity to understand something deeply in a way that is relevant to your life.

>>28237980
what it means to bring life to this world.
having children, becoming a parent
How does that change us?

posts.name: Monk
posts.com:
>>28238076
Well as far as becoming a parent in the world it's definitely something that puts you in a position of sincerity and brings a sense of constant meaningfulness into your life.

So naturally that's what a lot of people are going to strive towards or get attached to because we as human beings naturally need some way of living a meaningful life.

And being a parent having a child is a kind of sure way to experience that and so naturally people feel nourished they feel inspired they feel encouraged to live skillfully and to take care and you know this is how it all kind of works..

But we don't need to become a parent or to have a child necessarily to live a meaningful life.

We can seek out community, we can seek out high quality wisdom or compassion teachers, I find myself to really appreciate Buddhist teachers like Thich Nhat Hanh, Ajahn Brahm, Sister Dang nghiem.

Can all be found on YouTube...

And so we just kind of make our way of going in the direction of being more involved in life and living a more meaningful life.

And we can especially emphasize to be a good person and to be generous to do good deeds.

If you do good you feel good.

If you do bad you feel bad.

If you do more good and you do less bad you can do the math.

So the main thing we need to find out whether it's Buddhist or religious or atheist or whatever it is is how can we find supporting conditions in our life to do more good deeds and to reduce and step back from our unskilledful activities


It sounds very simple and intuitive but we need those reminders and those conditions to support us to continue doing that and not just stay in this animalistic realm of chasing after our desires and trying to avoid those things that are a little bit unpleasant.

So that's what I can offer now~

So a good way to begin into understanding Buddhism is to actually have an interest in understanding Buddhism.

If you have that then you can look into the book called

No mud no Lotus the art of transforming suffering by Thich Nhat Hanh

You can also look into the book what the Buddha taught by Walpola Rahula.

These are really great access points.

I've also set up a Discord server for anyone who's interested to talk with me or connect further about Buddhism and you can join that if you like.

https://discord.gg/Phrr5QKwqB

>>28238143
One of the primary practices that we do as monks is to practice celibacy.

So that doesn't mean that we don't have sexual energy or that we don't have difficulties in practicing that but it's this kind of constant direction we have in our life to transform sexual energy into our meditation practice into our wholesomeness into our focus on doing good deeds and being a support for other people on the path.
So that's a big focus of monk life is that practice of celibacy and transforming sexual energy to be something more meditative and wholesome.

But we don't believe that sex is in any way bad it's just that it takes a lot of energy and it can be very primal and selfish and desire focused so as monks we practice to let go of that more and more.

>>28238159
I think that truth can be found here in the present moment, so I feel that we all have an access to truth in the here and now.

And so naturally from that perspective or position I don't have any problem with other religions or other people's beliefs or other people's ways of going about the path.

As long as it helps them to be happy peaceful and transform suffering and also bring benefit to others then that's good I'm not so focused on debating about beliefs or complicated stories.

Whatever makes someone feel happy and at peace and free and helps them to share that with other people I feel that that's quite good.

Buddhism is also not exclusionary towards other religion

>>28238626
There's not really so much infighting between different schools of Buddhism but there is some people who focus on the differences and disagreements and give a lot of attention and energy to that.

But the basic principles of Buddhism are all philosophical and practice-based rather than religious based so in that way there are so many opportunities for coming together rather than debating or arguing.

But it does happen.

Yeah I'm super happy to help you with getting into Zen Buddhism That's what I'm really about.

Go ahead and search for "Bhante Varrapanyo" on YouTube and you'll find my channel.

My most recent video is like a 100% direct introduction to Zen Buddhism so I highly recommend you check it out I just finished recording it live so it's quite a fair place to start.

So don't focus too much on what you've wasted or what you've done wrong or even what you've done right up to this point.

Rather understand that through the power of doing good deeds, mindfulness, and a willingness to let go of your attachment to certain things in your life you can totally transform the state of your mind and the overall state of your life 100%.

Start by prioritizing to do good deeds more and more, to do acts of generosity, to be a good person.

So start to prioritize that and look deeply at that

Once you start to make that a priority you can notice those things in your life that might feel good but ultimately or not skillful that means they don't nourish you they don't feed you on your path.

So you do those things less and less.

Alternatively you make the decision to do more and more good deeds, acts of generosity, cleaning up your room, volunteering, going for a walk in nature, so many different opportunities but you just need to do and to act from that good intention and you can really start to transform your life 100% trust me.

Wish you the best of luck.

>>28238727
Breathing and aware of what is happening right now in the body.

Breathing and aware of what's happening right now in the mind.

Focusing on breathing and aware.

Focusing on to let go of your attachment to anything going a particular way or to any certain kind of experience


Aware of it but not hanging onto it not chasing after it not trying to get rid of it.

Just like looking at oneself in the mirror there's not so much to be confused about but it is interesting and curious.

Look in a similar way at those sufferings painful emotions difficulties that come up in the mind and body


Bring a sense of curiosity and willingness to feel that suffering a willingness to be with that suffering whatever it might be.

It can help if you focus on your breathing and take a deep breath and bring your mind home to the body and focus on feeling that feeling within the body


Now this is advanced practice this is not easy to do.

But at least you can bring that quality or that intention to your mind when those sufferings come up.

other than that you need to do more and more meaningful activities more and more doing good deeds more and more generosity more and more offering up what you have for the benefit of other people.

That kind of practice is going to plant a lot of seeds of happiness

>>28239671
My main teacher right now is in the Theravada school of Myanmar...
His main teaching is doing good deeds mindfulness and detachment and he's involved in a lot of social work.

Quite a mystical and Zen style monk...

And I myself find most of my appreciation in Buddhism to be directed towards a Zen style approach philosophy understanding etc.

That's what I mostly align with.

I think all the kinds of schools of Buddhism have a somewhat similar vein of understanding and teaching and practice.

Tibetan Buddhism stands out as having major differences.

And then there's also sectarian traditions within Mahayana or Theravada that can have strong differences.

In general though the basic principles of Buddhism are shared and they tend to be inclusive to one another outside of certain groups that are more conservative or attached to a particular way of doing things.

Appreciate your question and welcome to join the Discord and spend some time with the community and practice.

https://discord.gg/Phrr5QKwqB

The main issue is not to get trapped in constantly believing and fixating on our self-focus story.

Rather we should emphasize to do good deeds and do acts of generosity as much as we can.

We should emphasize through the power of the experience of the practice of giving up something that we hold to be valuable and exercising that.

We should focus to be mindful about what's happening in the present moment.

To be aware of the breathing.

To understand that your present moment breathing is way more valuable than gold.

So give your attention to it and in the process of giving your attention to the breathing let go of your complicated thinking worry belief in this story that you're telling yourself whether or not it's true is not so important but stop feeding this energy and this attention to the story and allow yourself to put that story down to put that situation down to put that person in that environment down and to simply be aware.

You remain true to yourself by being mindful by having a relationship with the present moment.

By having a relationship with your breathing and your capacity to be aware of something and to let it go and not get stuck on it.

Be patient be gentle be wholehearted to enjoy just breathing and just letting go Just breathing and being aware also definitely consider to scroll up and look at the other responses I've given and you can find some resources and information in there to support you on your path.

Good luck my friend, Don't worry it will be okay one way or another.

Even if everything doesn't work out and everything falls apart it'll still be okay.

The present moment will still be a doorway to freedom and peace.

There's not so much complicated thinking required to just take a bath to just breathe to just be aware.

posts.sub: I don't understand how to love
posts.com:
I'm a 26 year old virgin, never had a girlfriend, but i'm not an incel. I have plenty of friends, i'm pretty sociable and i've even turned girls down before. I feel like i could get a girlfriend if i wanted to, but at the same time i just don't feel the need to go after one. I've never really liked someone like that, so i don't know how its supposed to feel. I've always been a fan of romance, be it in movies, manga, books, whatever. I love reading romances where you get to see two characters fall in love with eachother, but it feels like a world far away i can never reach, like its not for me. Hell, i've been told multiple times that i'm good at relationship advice even though i've never had one.

I just can't imagine myself in a relationship, i can't imagine myself being intimate with someone, kissing them, hugging them, having sex. It just feels like it would be wrong. I don't understand how you're supposed to pass time together, with friends you can just peace out and be along again (i do like my alone time), but with a significant other do you just spend all time together? I just don't know how to do it. I can't imagine someone looking at me in that way. I am curious about romance of course, i wonder how it would be like to grow to love someome like that, but i think deep down i don't like myself enough to allow that kind of happiness, i feel like i would need to be a better person to deserve love, and i just don't love myself enough. My therapist keeps trying to convince me that i should look for someone, like that would change my outlook on life and allow me to be more positive about everything, but is that really true? Is love really that powerful of a force?

I don't really know what i'm asking exactly here, i just wanted to know if anyone feels or felt something similar i guess.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28239581
Look for the person you can become who you would allow to be happy, and let yourself grow into compatibility with the romance as you imagine it.
People with personalities homogenized to the crowd will have it easier finding people they are love-compatible with. As you grow your own personality, you will start to manifest in ways that will attract more and more people.
Start by looking at yourself, seeking your potential for growth, and will to grow into that place you would like.

Yes you have to risk yourself, no other choice. And hey.. you'll live anyway op.

>>28239529
In Virginia Woolf's Mrs Dalloway a woman does her morning's shopping. That's it - that's the whole story. But as she does, we learn a book's worth about her - and that has held the interest of readers for 100 years.

Some plot happens in The Great Gatsby, but all to the minor characters. Gatsby ends up exactly where he began - but how that happens to him is the whole book.

The point is that a novel is about character, psychology and creation of a world, not just plot. Make your characters and their world real enough and they don't have to do a lot.

Identify something you can work on and do it. You'll never feel like you're able to take on the big stuff if you can't do small things.

Peterson would say "clean your room", and from personal experience I think that's pretty good advice. I thin you probably feel like you need to fix it all quickly, but that's just not realistic for anyone. Start small and start right now.

>How to set and maintain boundaries?
To clarify, I was talking about *his* obligation to keep his distance. As in, he shouldn't be getting close to any woman he's not related to or in a relationship with. It's inappropriate and disrespectful towards any woman he does end up with. Mind you, getting into a series of sexual relationships is even worse. It's a separate obligation to not get sexual except with someone he commits to (his spouse).

If you're asking about how to check boundaries from your end, it's just a matter of being willing to hold people accountable. If they do something that you find wrong/inappropriate, then you have to be willing to walk out over that. Boundaries are very useful here because you don't need to stress over the truth of a messy situation (for example, a guy who went to a strip club but who insists "my friend dragged me there, I didn't do anything"), because getting into the situation itself is what crossed the boundary. Again, this is because good boundaries, either when you're following them yourself or holding others accountable by them, demand not only the right behavior but the appearance of doing the right thing. Having a gaggle of opposite-gender friends is not a good appearance.

You can rehabilitate your rating by buying Tinder Gold and setting your location to the Philippines for awhile. Buying Tinder Platinum is a way to bribe them into pretending your Elo rating is as good as Chad's so you can actually get matches again.

posts.sub: In this thread we are going to look for the cure for depression
posts.com:
I have no proof or medical studies to show that this is the case, but I also have no doubts. I believe that to get out of depression, tiredness, fatigue and all that shit, you first have to work your body, since a healthy body is a healthy mind, for that it is good to do sports, whatever it is. it is as long as it keeps our body busy. Another important factor is studying, it doesn't really matter what, it doesn't matter if it's for university, school or for yourself, you have to do it to keep your mind occupied with something productive. I would also say that looking for a job, or generating income with a startup, as this will keep our mind and body busy, while giving us money, in itself gives us a reason to keep going, especially when you are working on something of your own.

Another important point is to stop comparing yourself to others, stop thinking that the other is better than you because you have more knowledge, money or physical condition. It is also very silly to think about issues such as superiority or inferiority, we are all human, we all have problems and difficulties in life, of course there are degrees of this, but this does not have to be a limitation. You have to focus on yourself, on your problems, on your virtues, on your life, and not on that of others.

Another issue is guilt and remorse, which depending on the person can be the easiest part, or difficult to overcome, because it is easy to forgive others, but sometimes it is difficult, if not impossible, to forgive yourself. No matter how dirty your hands are, they can always be cleaned. You have to accept your sins, accept what you did wrong and live with it. Go to a priest, a psychologist, or tell someone you trust what you did, this can help, it doesn't matter if you think psychology is a joke, or if you don't believe in God, the important thing is to somehow get the weight off What are you wearing.

posts.com: think you need to begin with the question of why do people in general feel emotions to begin to answer why someone would fall into a perpetual negative emotional state. Emotions are clearly intrinsic instincts not learned although learned experiences can change what triggers the emotions to occur. These instincts evolved over time to prod people towards the actions that have proven to be evolutionarily successful over time. Because people are highly social animals and there is fierce competition between different social groups of people, many of the emotions we feel are actually designed to not simply benefit yourself and improve your own survival, but to benefit the survival of the entire social group. These instincts go hand in hand with developed cultural mores.

It all comes down to conditioning.

From the most recent trigger or episode to your emotional trauma that sets off depression.
Or the cycle of trauma and pain you repeat and keep yourself in.
Down to traumatic events that have a lifelong impact on your psyche.

The necessary systems in place for recovery are 'safety', 'hope of recovery and future', an environment that fosters these two things as well as the social justice aspect, meaning you get the recognition of trauma you were dealt and the perpetrator dealt with. (but in the case of Act of God events, it's rationalisation through the reality of what happened)

This means, identifying things in your environment and social groups as well as your past, that negatively affect you. Doing your best to distance and remove those obstacles in your life and then having the 'stability' of an environment that is conducive to positive feedback cycles and a normalisation of ptsd behaviour responses in order to become and feel normal.

Lack of hope is another big reason, but this falls back to conditioning and a lack of positive feedback cycles fueling your worldview. If your metaphysical understanding of the universe is lacking, you won't see the point of your individualism in the big picture.
>seek god
>or develop another useful schema (evolution)


Depression is just when life beats you down and you lack the insight and motivation or opportunity to actually make a change. It's as simple as that.
And if you say your family has a history of depression, then that's just generational conditioning that has left your psyche disordered in order to grow somehow. Your ancestors fought through their environments to overcome depression, as should you etc.

We cannot say whether or not you should take antidepressants, you must attend one or two sessions with a psychiatrist and tell him about your problems, and he will determine whether or not you have depression. You can be a functional, charismatic person, who bathes, goes to work, studies, and does everything well, but if apathy (loss of interest in things), a feeling of emptiness, and physical symptoms such as fatigue from nothing , then you may have depression, especially with those suicidal thoughts that you have.
Therapy can also help, but if you go to several sessions, tell them all your problems and see that it doesn't help you, it's better to change someone better. Do not stay with the first option, if you do not like something you are always free to go and change.

>>28216868
Here’s you. You don’t know yourself very well.

And over there is society, your parents, peers etc. Tv screens, schools… They’ve been telling you all your life what a “good person” is. Maybe you felt you are not good enough the way you are.

That causes trauma. Sounds dramatic, but all it means is that pain causes you to reject certain aspects of yourself.

This rejection functions by repression, preventing who you are from being made conscious. And therefore you have low self-awareness. You also have a feeling of need. You don’t feel whole.

For the places where you rejected yourself, you do not know what you really want. You’ve disconnected from yourself. Instead, what you’re doing is aspiring to make yourself conform to the image society has programmed onto you. This is the trap of self-image.

The maintenance of a self-image is a burden, motivated by anxiety and pain. You may be good at it, or you may be so handicapped by it, that it extinguishes you, and it completely prevents you from knowing what you actually want.

In the latter example, you are sure you know what you want, you just “can’t get yourself to do it”. It is the poor self-awareness at work, because of the trauma. And that is how you get depressed.

It is getting stuck in a lie, that you are unwilling to let go of (that you have to be/do better), because you are sure that you are worthless as you are.

>>28216868
I think the most important thing is a combination of social support and validation.

Some seek validation through sex or long-term relationships, or through their careers. Without this, people will doubt themselves and have low confidence. Sometimes validation can be internal, but that requires an unusually strong moral foundation and a lot of willpower. Most people will seek this through social interactions. I honestly believe that being romantically valued is vital to a persons mental health - you are being judged by another person and found worthy of their commitment and attention. Social media is being used as a replacement for IRL validation, and we all see how that's going.

The requirement for social support is a phycological need to know that you have a safety net (social, emotional and physical) in case something goes wrong that you can't handle on your own. If you don't have this support you'll be subconsciously aware of your own vulnerability to disasters, like medical emergencies or times of hardship. Humans are pack animals, and knowing that you have a "tribe" that has your back is a very primal need for us. The state to some extent has fulfilled the "physical" aspect, but not the emotional or social.

In my experience both personal and from observing others, these two needs are absolute and cannot be replaced. Trying to substitute them with other distractions is only a temporary measure and will eventually fail.

>>28239248
That's not normal. I can see why your girlfriend thinks you might be autistic. I don't think you're autistic, but from the outside, this definitely would LOOK like autism. It sounds like you can't communicate socially in a normal way.

Conversations are indeed transactional.
Conversations are an opportunity to learn about the other person, and to tell them a bit about yourself. It's a way of getting closer to them. In order to get closer to a person, you can't just ignore the stuff you're not interested in. You have to acknowledge things that THEY care about, because those things are important to who they are. Both parties have to make an effort to show interest in the other person (ask questions and get to know them) and also to express themselves.
You're doing one half of the conversational transaction correctly (telling people about things you care about, and showing you care by perking up when those topics come up). But you're failing to meet the other half of your obligation (talking to people about things THEY care about). You have to put some effort into that shit.

If you don't put that effort in, it can give people the impression that you're kind of an asshole, or you straight-up just don't give a shit about them as people. Your girlfriend obviously knows that you're not an asshole, but she does see that your conversational skills are pretty shit, and she's trying to figure out what the issue is. She reckons it's autism, and frankly, I can see why. Autistic people often make this mistake.
For real, bro. Get checked out. It's not a big deal.

Relationships like the friendship you described are pretty rare, IME. Most people can click to some degree, but effortless conversations like the ones you were able to have with that friend are rare. I've only ever experienced it with a handful of people, and even then - the vibe can change as you grow apart, or change with time. It's a rare pleasure. Hold on to people like that.

>>28239419
Why does it make you sad?

To be clear: when I say conversations are 'transactional', I'm not saying that each person is trying to 'get something out of it'. It's more like...
Ok, so let's say your mother is super nurturing and loving. She looks after the whole household, right?
But let's say that your dad is kind of a dick and he doesn't pull his weight around the house. So she eventually stops doing his laundry for him, and doesn't cook meals that he requests - instead opting to put her efforts towards caring more for the kids. That's a transaction. In this case, your dad isn't putting in effort to DESERVE her care. She was already putting in the effort, purely out of love.

Conversations are kind of like that. You put in the effort to show respect for the other person and to create a bridge to ALLOW them to get to know you. It's not about what you want, but about treating other people as equals and showing care for them. If a person never shows interest in you, it's a bit like a slap in the face, right? That's when most people stop putting effort into the conversation - once the other person has acted like a dick.

>>28239023
Rest every Saturday, do not allow yourself to work.
You decided the major you chose because a part of you liked it, you just forgot along the way what caused it. You are simply worn out.
Eat good healthy food, and drink lots of good bottled water (not 'filtered' tap water).
The fact that you see is, you are trapped! But we all are, and at this time in your life you are put to a test few who are older truly understand, the complexity of adjusting to life independent.

Do not depend on your relationship for happiness.

When you allow yourself to rest, you will rejuvenate what has been worn down by overwork. Understand that you are working on pharaoh's pyramid, which pharaoh is capital interest, which has enslaved all of society, and dictates the terms of your life. Seek life in spite of this.
Seek the society of friends. Do not look at the social status hierarchy, looking up with fear, and down with disrespect, but detach yourself from it, and see it all for what it is, a mountain of suffering. Shit rolls down hill, they say; doesn't mean you can't close your mouth.
Find the fully developed happy man you can be when you just sit there and think. Learn the value of positive self thought, self declaration. Tell yourself to look forward to growth in spite of trials.

Do not depend on entertainment for happiness either. Develop your own self into self-sufficiency for happiness. You are missing some voices in your head that maybe you only heard sparingly growing up (support from parents, friends) or maybe you implicitly reject (often people's self-criticism monologue will try to monopolize thought by decrying self-positive monologue as cringe, do not let self-hate dominate your personality, keep it in check; do not internalize the pain the world wishes for you, but grow in favor of the potential happiness in spite of the world).

Hope this helps

Practice and usefull tips and "tricks". A good example is cooking, having a properworkflow and using the right technique can half the time it takes. For example if your cutting up a chicken breast into cubes slicing a single strip off and cutting that into cube by cube individually takes forever. If you cut every strip in one pass then stack them together and cut every strip into a cube in one slice you spend less than half the time doing that task. Same for everything else there is often a proper or more effective way of going about it. For learning its note taking, writing things down, instead of just reading them, and ging over it consistently. You can learn these through practice or researching from others who have the experience you do not. Take your time and find what works for you on a case by case basis.

you're probably fine, just maintain contact with her and pay attention to how long it takes for her to respond, read body language, etc.

Think of them like cats, if you always run up to a cat and pick it up, it's not gonna like you. If you're chillin with the cat, give it a little affection, and let it walk away and come back, it'll like you. That's kinda how it be in the beginning

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Did you like the talking? Was she cool? Did she think you were an alright fellow? Or was she bored?
The fuck up is overthinking it. Don't disturb the way things happen naturally.
Sometimes you meet someone, and while no immediate potential for romance is apparent (to the girl), long-term things could go any way. Don't fool yourself into thinking you need to force an issue. Let things drift apart even, and maybe they will come together at a later time.

Something tells me you're a younger man, freshmen/sophomore etc. Develop your character first, value in your personality, and people will be attracted by what you bring to the table. Don't try to compel people to take what you're offering, in stead play it cool in all situations. Give people a slice of yourself to try as they ask for it.
Learn also to help those who are less mature and capable of friendship into growing to be more self aware, more cognizant of others' thoughts. But help yourself first. Good luck

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28238617
That's OCD.

Literally the only way to combat the compulsion to wash your hands is by challenging it and saying "get fucked, brain. Dirty hands gang."

I don't have OCD, but I had OCD-type thoughts about colours. I would associate a colour with a fictional character, and then I physically could not bring myself to touch that colour, or I would be really anxious and upset, thinking that the character was real, and could read my mind. I knew it wasn't real, but the feeling persisted.
You probably know logically that your hands are fine and you won't get sick, but the feeling that you MUST WASH persists.
In my case, these thoughts consumed everything. I would lay in bed naked, surrounded by white sheets (white was the only 'safe' colour). I couldn't sit comfortably on coloured chairs. I would avoid wearing the clean clothes in my wardrobe because they had splashes of red or green on them. It fucking sucked.
But I cured myself by simply choosing to stop. I almost never think about that shit anymore. It does crop up from time to time when my mental health is generally not great (eg: from personal stresses like work or family drama), but it's extremely mild and I never give in to it.

IME, the ONLY FUCKING WAY to improve is by doing the following:
>Acknowledge your compulsion to wash
>Turn it over in your head and think about why you feel the need to do this
>Analyse your thought process and realise how insane and neurotic you're being, and how unnecessary all this washing really is
>Refuse to wash your hands (until you use the bathroom or something lol)
>Force yourself to stew in the anxiety and discomfort
>Do not give in.
>If you catch yourself performing other 'soothing' actions, like wiping your hands on your jeans to 'wipe them clean', stop yourself.
>Instead, distract yourself by focusing on something else. Play videogames or something
>Wash, rinse, repeat (lmao) until the compulsion calms down.

This is a misnomer.
Debt is a motivator. You pay off the debt, with money leftover, simple, you also bump up your credit score that way. Money is just a tool that can help you along and get through life far easier than without.
>mortgages
Owning your own house or at least a patch of land for a trailer is better than always paying for things you never own. That's renting, only useful in the short term. Own your own stuff, but always have a way to pay for it, consider having multiple streams of income.

>Car Loans
In many places you need a car, and it's far more expensive to rideshare than to own your own car, and take care of it, so you're better off with a car that you own, that you can drive anywhere you want.

>Bills
This is practically unavoidable. With the internet, heat/air conditioning, electricity, and most other things, they cost money, of which can be heavily minimalized, but some bills are unavoidable. Best to just deal with the bills as they come, as all properties have some form of maintenance. If you're looking for a home that's pretty self-sufficient, check out earthships.

>Women
This I can agree with. There's no bigger debt accumulator than a woman.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Flirting is like an impromptu date. You are finding out if this person is more than just a pretty face. You ask questions about them and present your best self to them.

Flirting is appropriate if you're getting positive body language back. If the other person is looking away, giving short answers, or seems distracted, exit as gracefully as possible. Avoid startling the other party by just showing up out of nowhere, try to get at least one decent eye contact first.

Also if they just straight up ask "Are you flirting with me?" pull a Chad move and say "Yeah, how's it working?" And if they dismiss you, say "Well, you were worth a shot."
